metadata.titleEn: 0.25-degree gridded daily maximum and minimum temperature， wind speed and  precipitation on the Qinghai Tibet Plateau and its surroundings (1957-2020)
metadata.description: 0.25-degree long-term historical daily temperature maxima and minima, precipitation and wind speed can be used to study climate change on the Tibetan Plateau and its surroundings in the past decades during 1957-2020. This data set can also be used to force macro-scale hydrological and dynamic vegetation model in the region. The procedure to generate the data set is based on Cuo et al. (2013) published in Journal of Climate. The source data collected to generate the gridded data set come from China Meteorological Agency and NOAA-GHCND. In total, 446, 435, 966 and 427 stations were used to generate grids of temperature maxima, temperature minima, precipitation, and wind speed, respectively. The area coverage of the data set is 24.125-41.875N，69.625-105.875E.
metadata.instructions: Take a file name “data_41.875_71.125” as an example, 41.875 is latitude, 71.125 is longitude.  So the file name tells the location of the data. The data are saved as ASCII format, there are four columns in each file, they are precipitation, temperature maxima, temperature minima and wind speed, respectively. There are 8300 grid cells covering the region. Use tar -xzf grid_0.25_prec_tmax_tmin_wind_tps.gz  to decompress and extract.

literatureList.titleEn: Climate Change on the Northern Tibetan Plateau during 1957–2009: Spatial Patterns and Possible Mechanisms
literatureList.referenceEn: Cuo, L., Zhang, Y., Wang, Q., & Zhang, L., et al. (2013). Climate Change on the Northern Tibetan Plateau during 1957–2009: Spatial Patterns and Possible Mechanisms. Journal of Climate, 26, 85-109.

background: The Tibetan Plateau (TP) exerts significant influence on regional and global climate through thermal and mechanical forcing. As a headwater region of the Yellow, Yangtze, and Mekong Rivers, the northern Tibetan Plateau (NTP) provides water for more than a billion people and numerous ecosystems in China and Southeast Asia. Near-surface air temperature increases in the recent decades have been documented over the TP based primarily on isolated station observations. Changes in precipitation over the TP, however, do not show consistent and plateau-wide trends both temporally and spatially. The lack of consistent trends in station records of precipitation likely reflects the consequences of multiple drivers acting in numerous ways and differentially affecting climatic variability in various parts of the region. Gridded data interpolated from station observations can be used to examine regional climate change in a more spatiotemporally complete manner than is generally possible with station records alone. Over the TP, with a surface area larger than Greenland and complex terrain, it is often challenging to generate gridded climate data of good quality.
research objective: One objective of this study is to introduce and evaluate the new gridded daily climate dataset including precipitation, surface air temperature minima and maxima, and wind speed spanning 1957 to 2009 over the NTP. Another objective is to employ the new dataset to diagnose regional climate change signals over the NTP and investigate possible causal mechanisms. This study also examines changes in snowfall over the NTP during 1957–2009.
challenges: Over the TP, with a surface area larger than Greenland and complex terrain, it is often challenging to generate gridded climate data of good quality. Global atmospheric reanalyses have been proven useful for climate change analysis in many regions of the world; however, they have limitations over the TP due to the coarse resolution and inadequate constraint of atmospheric conditions.
methods: The Pearson’s correlations between precipitation–wind speed and indices of large-scale weather systems including the WJ, NAO, AO, and ENSO were examined for four subregions in the NTP during 1957–2009. In addition, the EAM and SAM indices were examined for June, July, and August when 70% of wet season precipitation falls. The EAM and SAM indices were downloaded from the web http://ljp.lasg.ac.cn/dct/page/65544) and were derived using the approach detailed by Li and Zeng (2002). Indices for winter monsoons were not provided by Li and Zeng (2002). The NAO and AO indices were obtained from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Climate Prediction Center (CPC) website (http://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/precip/CWlink/). The Multivariate ENSO Index (MEI) was provided by the NOAA Earth System Research Laboratory (ESRL) (at http://www.esrl.noaa.gov/psd/enso/mei/table.html). The WJ index was calculated based on the method suggested by Duan and Wu (2009).
dataset: In total, 81 stations that have daily records of precipitation, 2-m temperature minima and maxima, and 10-m wind speed were used. The only high-resolution gridded dataset that is available for the TP is the 0.2583 0.258 Asian Precipitation–Highly Resolved Observational Data Integration toward the Evaluation of Water Resources–Monsoon Asia (APHRODITE-MA) products compiled by Yatagai et al. (2009) for 1951–2007. By comparison, we introduce an up-to-date (through 2009) gridded climatic dataset that employs an expanded network of station records for the NTP (81 in total).
findings: The Mann–Kendall trends of various climate elements of the gridded data show that NTP has in general experienced annually increasing temperature and decreasing wind speed but spatially varied precipitation changes. Snowfall has decreased along high mountain ranges during the wet and warm season. Averaged over the entire NTP, snowfall, temperature minima and maxima, and wind speed experienced statistically significant linear trends at rates of -0.52 mm yr21 (water equivalent), 0.048Cy r21, 0.038Cy r21, and -0.01 m s21 yr21, respectively.

Verification.Question: Is it possible to use gridded data interpolated from station observations to examine regional climate change more comprehensively than using station records alone?
Does the creation of high-quality gridded climate data over the Tibetan Plateau face significant challenges due to its complex terrain and large surface area?
Is there a new gridded daily climate dataset available that includes precipitation, surface air temperature minima and maxima, and wind speed for analysis over the Northern Tibetan Plateau?

Disjunctive.Question: Which data collection method is more suitable for generating high-quality gridded climate data in complex terrains like the Tibetan Plateau: isolated station observations, global atmospheric reanalyses, or other techniques?
What is a more effective source for indices used in climate analysis for the Tibetan Plateau region: the NOAA Climate Prediction Center, the NOAA Earth System Research Laboratory, or other sources?

Which datasets provide a more comprehensive analysis of the climate change signals over the Tibetan Plateau: the APHRODITE-MA products or more recent gridded climatic datasets with expanded station networks?
Disjunctive.Answer: more recent gridded climatic datasets with expanded station networks

Who provides the original station data used in climate datasets for the Tibetan Plateau?
Where can indices for large-scale weather systems like the NAO and AO be obtained for research purposes?
Concept Completion.Answer: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Climate Prediction Center

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a challenge faced when generating gridded climate data for the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: A significant challenge is dealing with the complex terrain and large surface area of the Tibetan Plateau, which makes it difficult to generate high-quality gridded climate data.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of gridded climate data for the Tibetan Plateau and its surrounding areas?
Feature Specification.Answer: 0.25 degrees spatial resolution, daily records of maximum and minimum temperatures, wind speed, precipitation, period from 1957 to 2020

Feature Specification.Question: What are the challenges faced in generating high-quality gridded climate data over the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: complex terrain, large surface area, coarse resolution, inadequate constraint of atmospheric conditions

Quantification.Question: How many original stations were used for collecting maximum temperature data?
What spatial resolution is used for the gridded climate data over the Tibetan Plateau and surrounding areas?

Definition.Question: What does 'gridded climate data' mean in the context of analyzing climate change over complex terrains like the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: Gridded climate data refers to datasets that are spatially interpolated from station observations, allowing for a more complete examination of regional climate change across large and complex terrains such as the Tibetan Plateau. This method is used to overcome the challenges posed by isolated station observations that may not fully capture the spatial and temporal variability of climate changes over such vast areas.

Definition.Question: What are 'global atmospheric reanalyses' and how do they relate to limitations in studying climate change over areas like the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: Global atmospheric reanalyses are datasets that provide comprehensive atmospheric data by assimilating observations from various sources into a consistent model framework. They are useful for climate change analysis globally but have limitations over the Tibetan Plateau due to their coarse resolution and inadequate constraint of atmospheric conditions, which can affect the quality of climate data generated for such regions.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'Mann–Kendall trends' in the context of analyzing climate elements over a given region?
Definition.Answer: Mann–Kendall trends refer to a statistical method used to detect trends in climate data over time. In the context of the Tibetan Plateau, this method is employed to identify trends in various climate elements such as temperature, wind speed, precipitation, and snowfall, providing insights into how these elements have changed over the region during the study period.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method using station observations compare to using gridded data interpolated from station observations in terms of spatiotemporal completeness over the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: Gridded data interpolated from station observations can provide a more spatiotemporally complete examination of regional climate change compared to isolated station observations, which tend to lack consistent trends across the plateau.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in data accuracy and resolution between the high-resolution APHRODITE-MA dataset and a newly introduced gridded dataset for the northern Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: The high-resolution APHRODITE-MA dataset provides detailed data for 1951–2007, while a newly introduced dataset for the northern Tibetan Plateau offers up-to-date data through 2009 with an expanded network of station records. Both aim to provide high-resolution climatic data, but the new dataset includes additional station data for more recent years.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges of generating gridded climate data over the Tibetan Plateau compare to those faced when using global atmospheric reanalyses for climate change analysis?
Comparison.Answer: Generating gridded climate data over the Tibetan Plateau is challenging due to its complex terrain, while global atmospheric reanalyses are limited by coarse resolution and inadequate constraint of atmospheric conditions specifically over the plateau. Both methods face difficulties, but gridded data generation is particularly hindered by the terrain complexity.

Interpretation.Question: How might the challenges of generating gridded climate data over complex terrains like the Tibetan Plateau influence the interpretation of climate trends?
Interpretation.Answer: Over the Tibetan Plateau, with its complex terrain, generating high-quality gridded climate data is challenging. These challenges can affect the interpretation of climate trends as global atmospheric reanalyses are often limited due to coarse resolution and inadequate constraint of atmospheric conditions. This may lead to less accurate or inconsistent climate trend analysis.

Interpretation.Question: What implications do the varying spatial and temporal trends in precipitation data have for understanding regional climate changes in the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: The varying spatial and temporal trends in precipitation data suggest that multiple drivers are differentially affecting climatic variability across various parts of the Tibetan Plateau. This inconsistency indicates that regional climate changes might be influenced by complex interactions of different climatic factors, making it difficult to identify clear trends without comprehensive gridded data.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the examination of correlations between precipitation, wind speed, and large-scale weather system indices contribute to understanding climate dynamics in the northern Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: Examining correlations between precipitation, wind speed, and large-scale weather system indices like the WJ, NAO, AO, and ENSO can provide insights into the climate dynamics in the northern Tibetan Plateau. Such analysis helps in diagnosing regional climate change signals and investigating possible causal mechanisms, thus contributing to a more nuanced understanding of how these factors interact and influence climate variability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in generating high-quality gridded climate data for regions with complex terrains like the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: One challenge in generating high-quality gridded climate data for regions like the Tibetan Plateau is the complex terrain, which makes it difficult to interpolate data accurately. Global atmospheric reanalyses have limitations in these areas due to their coarse resolution and inadequate constraint of atmospheric conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do precipitation trends over the Tibetan Plateau not show consistent patterns both temporally and spatially?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The lack of consistent trends in precipitation over the Tibetan Plateau likely reflects the impact of multiple drivers that affect climatic variability in various ways, influencing different parts of the region differently.

Causal Consequence.Question: What consequences arise in generating gridded climate data when dealing with complex terrain such as the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Over the Tibetan Plateau, which has a surface area larger than Greenland and complex terrain, generating gridded climate data of good quality is challenging. The complexity often leads to difficulties in ensuring accuracy and consistency in the data, as evidenced by the need for an expanded network of station records and the limitations of global atmospheric reanalyses due to coarse resolution and inadequate constraint of atmospheric conditions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects of using an expanded network of station records on the quality of a climate dataset for the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using an expanded network of station records for the Tibetan Plateau can improve the spatiotemporal completeness and accuracy of the gridded climate dataset. This approach helps overcome the limitations of isolated station observations and enables a more detailed examination of regional climate change signals, providing a more reliable dataset for analyzing temperature, precipitation, and wind speed trends.

Causal Consequence.Question: What impact does the lack of consistent temporal and spatial precipitation trends have on data interpolation for climate studies over the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The lack of consistent temporal and spatial precipitation trends on the Tibetan Plateau means that data interpolation from station observations can be challenging. It reflects the influence of multiple drivers affecting climatic variability in different parts of the region, which can complicate efforts to generate reliable gridded climate data. This variability necessitates careful consideration of large-scale weather systems and indices when interpolating data for comprehensive climate studies.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to generate a high-resolution gridded climate dataset for the Tibetan Plateau and surrounding regions from 1957 to 2020?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Generating a high-resolution gridded climate dataset for the Tibetan Plateau and surrounding regions is important because it helps analyze the spatial and temporal climate change characteristics over the area. Such datasets can serve as crucial driving data for large-scale hydrological and ecological models, providing a more comprehensive understanding of regional climate dynamics compared to isolated station observations.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the main objectives behind employing a new gridded daily climate dataset, including precipitation, surface air temperature minima and maxima, and wind speed over the northern Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objectives behind employing a new gridded daily climate dataset over the northern Tibetan Plateau are to diagnose regional climate change signals and investigate possible causal mechanisms. This approach also seeks to analyze changes in snowfall during 1957–2009, offering deeper insights into the climatic variability and trends within the region.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it challenging to generate good quality gridded climate data for the Tibetan Plateau, and what methods are used to address these challenges?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Generating good quality gridded climate data for the Tibetan Plateau is challenging due to its complex terrain and large surface area. To address these challenges, methods such as examining Pearson’s correlations between climate elements and large-scale weather system indices are used. These techniques help account for the impacts of various climatic drivers and improve the accuracy and completeness of the gridded data.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of global atmospheric reanalyses contribute to climate change analysis over regions with limited station coverage?
Enablement.Answer: Global atmospheric reanalyses have been proven useful for climate change analysis in many regions of the world. However, their integration over the Tibetan Plateau is limited by coarse resolution and inadequate constraint of atmospheric conditions, indicating a need for methods that can compensate for these limitations.

Enablement.Question: What are the enabling factors for expanding the network of station records for climate datasets in regions like the northern Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Expanding the network of station records involves employing an up-to-date gridded climatic dataset that integrates a larger number of daily records from meteorological stations. This expansion is crucial for improving the accuracy and resolution of climate datasets over the northern Tibetan Plateau.

Expectation.Question: Why might generating high-quality gridded climate data over the Tibetan Plateau be challenging despite the availability of station records?
Expectation.Answer: Over the Tibetan Plateau, with a large surface area and complex terrain, it is challenging to generate gridded climate data of good quality. Global atmospheric reanalyses have limitations due to coarse resolution and inadequate constraint of atmospheric conditions.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated outcomes of using indices of large-scale weather systems in examining climate changes over the northern Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Using indices of large-scale weather systems like the WJ, NAO, AO, and ENSO can help in understanding the correlations between these systems and regional climate variables such as precipitation and wind speed during specific periods.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be inconsistencies in precipitation trends over the Tibetan Plateau, as observed through station records?
Expectation.Answer: The lack of consistent trends in station records of precipitation likely reflects the consequences of multiple drivers acting in numerous ways and differentially affecting climatic variability in various parts of the region.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using gridded climate data over isolated station observations for analyzing climate change in complex terrains like the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: Gridded data interpolated from station observations can provide a more spatiotemporally complete analysis of regional climate change than isolated station records alone, especially over complex terrains such as the Tibetan Plateau.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential limitations of global atmospheric reanalyses when applied to regions like the Tibetan Plateau, and how might these limitations affect climate data quality?
Judgmental.Answer: Global atmospheric reanalyses have limitations over the Tibetan Plateau due to their coarse resolution and inadequate constraint of atmospheric conditions, which can pose challenges in generating high-quality gridded climate data for this region.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how can the integration of expanded station records improve the accuracy of climate datasets for regions with sparse observation networks like the Northern Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration of an expanded network of station records can improve the accuracy of climate datasets by providing more comprehensive coverage, which is particularly valuable in regions with sparse observation networks like the Northern Tibetan Plateau.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how data collection challenges are addressed when generating gridded climate data in regions with complex terrain like the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: Over the Tibetan Plateau, generating high-quality gridded climate data is challenging due to its large surface area and complex terrain. Global atmospheric reanalyses, although useful in many regions, face limitations here because of coarse resolution and inadequate constraint of atmospheric conditions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the potential benefits and limitations of using gridded datasets over isolated station observations for climate change analysis in regions with complex terrains.
Request/Directive.Answer: Gridded datasets provide a more spatiotemporally complete representation of regional climate change compared to isolated station observations, which can be sparse and unevenly distributed. They help in capturing the climatic variability more comprehensively across regions with complex terrains like the Tibetan Plateau. However, generating these datasets can be challenging due to the need for high-resolution data and accurate interpolation methods. Despite these challenges, gridded datasets are advantageous in examining regional trends and patterns in climate change that may not be evident from station data alone.
